q: What are the main causes of high cholesterol?
a: The main causes of high cholesterol are eating fatty food, not exercising enough, being overweight, smoking, drinking alcohol, and genetics.

q: How can you lower your cholesterol?
a: You can lower your cholesterol by eating healthily and getting more exercise. Some people may also need to take medication.

q: What are the health risks associated with high cholesterol?
a: High cholesterol can increase the risk of heart problems and stroke by blocking blood vessels.

q: What are the symptoms of high cholesterol?
a: High cholesterol does not cause symptoms. It can only be diagnosed through a blood test.

q: Where can I find more information about inherited high cholesterol at a young age?
a: You can find more information about inherited high cholesterol at a young age (familial hypercholesterolaemia) on the Heart UK website.

q: What is high cholesterol?
a: High cholesterol is when you have too much of a fatty substance called cholesterol in your blood.

q: What are the causes of high cholesterol?
a: High cholesterol is mainly caused by eating fatty food, not exercising enough, being overweight, smoking, and drinking alcohol.

q: How can you lower your cholesterol?
a: You can lower your cholesterol by eating healthily and getting more exercise. Some people also need to take medicine.

q: What are the risks of high cholesterol?
a: Too much cholesterol can block your blood vessels and make you more likely to have heart problems or a stroke.

q: How can high cholesterol be diagnosed?
a: High cholesterol does not cause symptoms. You can only find out if you have it from a blood test.

q: What is familial hypercholesterolaemia?
a: Familial hypercholesterolaemia is inherited high cholesterol that starts at a young age. You can find more information about it on the Heart UK website.
